Background Welding fumes from industrial operations pose serious health risks. This study aimed to investigate the factors driving changes in welding fume exposure by analyzing key factors using the Advanced REACH Tool (ART) for dust exposure assessment in building materials enterprises. Methods The dust exposure of 18 building materials enterprises was compared using ART model assessments and measured data. Multiple covariance analysis identified key influencing factors consistent with field conditions. Finally, correlation and regression analyses evaluated the relationships between these factors and dust exposure. Results The ART model showed the highest agreement with field data at the 95th percentile. Correlation and regression analyses identified moisture content, surface contamination/emissions, and dust particle size as the main influencing factors. Conclusion Mitigating occupational health risks requires prioritized control of moisture content, followed by dust particle size and surface contamination/emission. Targeted control of these parameters supports actionable strategies to reduce occupational health risks from welding fume exposure. They are mainly engaged in processing, manufacturing, and selling welding operations. Welding fumes may be generated during welding processes, such as during electric welding and gas welding. Their typical work day lasted for 8 hours, and their main occupational disease hazard is the welding fumes that are generated during the processing of building materials. Welding fume mass concentrations were determined for each of the 18 construction material enterprises through quadruplicate measurements using the filtration membrane gravimetric method, with mass quantification performed via electronic analytical balance. The measurements obtained by this method do not include chemical fumes, solvents, or gases. 2.2 ART exposure assessment model ART is a semiquantitative model designed to improve the accuracy and utility of occupational exposure assessments. As a methodology for assessing the risk of exposure to chemicals in the workplace, the ART model has significant advantages in predicting the level of exposure to chemicals at a given site [ 19 Forward exposure assessment refers to the process of calculating the potential concentration of chemical substances to which workers may be exposed on the basis of known working environmental conditions and their relative probabilities as defined in the CPTs. This reflects the derivation from known exposure scenarios to the extent of exposure. Inverse assessment, in contrast, involves extrapolating the likelihood of various working conditions that contribute to a concentration level after it is known to have occurred, i.e., updating the probability of the conditions on the basis of the results, which is commonly used for risk management and the development of exposure precautions in the work environment. This approach is often used for risk management and the development of exposure-prevention measures in work environments. More complex risk assessments can be performed via this model, allowing safety engineers and health professionals to consider the entire exposure status, including multivariate factors such as the frequency of chemical use and work patterns. The superiority of the ART model in predicting occupational exposures has been demonstrated in numerous real-world applications through the validation of field data and the integration and analysis of existing research results [ 20 Fig. 1 21 Fig. 1 Flowchart of the ART model. Local control Control measures in close proximity of the source intended to remove emissions (e.g., LEV, wet suppression techniques). Firstly, the Kendall rank correlation coefficient matrix is used to evaluate the nonlinear correlation between variables. The advantage of this method is that it does not rely on the assumption of data normality and is robust to outliers. It can effectively identify the similarity pattern among different enterprises or business unit parameters and quantify the key drivers of risk exposure [ 22 23 3 Results 3.1 Analysis of exposure assessment 3.1.1 The ART model evaluation results The exposure period for each segment was determined. The exposure period is the measured time for which workers are exposed to welding fumes and the rest of the time is the non-exposure period. Exposure sessions are constructed on the basis of measured information from the work session combined with the influencing factors provided in the ART, which includes 10 categories of influencing factors: exposure duration, dust particle size, moisture content, mass fraction, activity emission potential, local control, segregation, dispersion, individual separation, and surface contamination/emissions. This finding suggests possible bias in the model’s prediction of low- and intermediate-level exposure, which may be due to model assumptions, uncertainty in the input parameters, or the complexity of site conditions. To analyze the causes of these phenomena in depth, we performed a correlation analysis and regression analysis to study the influencing factors in assessments with the ART model to identify those that cause changes in the exposure to welding fumes during welding operations. 3.2 Screening of influencing factors The scenarios demanded by some of the influencing factors in the ART model did not match the actual welding operation scenarios in 18 building materials enterprises, and these influencing factors are not fully applicable to the calculation of exposure to welding fumes. Therefore, to ensure the accuracy and applicability of the assessment results, we used IBM SPSS Statistics Version 29 statistical analysis software to screen the influencing factors that could be used for further analysis. After covariates were removed, eight influencing factors, namely, exposure duration, dust particle size, moisture content, local control, segregation, dispersion, individual separation, surface contamination/emissions, were diagnosed by multiple covariates [variance inflation factor (VIF) < 10] and were suitable for use in the next stage of the analysis of influencing factors as shown in Table 6 Table 6 Assessment of key influencing factors of welding fume exposure and their variance inflation factors (VIF) Table 6 Factor VIF Exposure duration 2.30 Dust particle size 2.36 Moisture content 3.62 Local control 4.03 Segregation 3.49 Dispersion 4.52 Individual separation 2.32 Surface contamination/emissions 9.16 3.3 Quantification of ART model influences The ART model is a semiquantitative assessment model and there are no strict quantitative indicators for the selection of model parameters. However, the ART model scores the influencing factors during the assessment, and the combination effect among the influencing factors can be described via the scoring multiplication mechanism. This assumes a simple multiplicative relationship among the factors and may not be able to comprehensively capture the complex interactions among the factors, especially when there is a nonlinear relationship or interaction effect relationship. Notably, the influence factor score provided by the ART model was selected on the basis of the degree of influence of a particular factor on the assessment results. For some influencing factors, such as the moisture content of the product, the higher the moisture content was, the lower the score was. In the analysis, the results of this type of parameter were affected. To facilitate the analysis, hierarchical analysis was adopted on the basis of the ART model score, which is divided into levels 1–5, to reassign quantitative values to the influencing factors. According to the quantitative standard, a model score of 0–0.02 was quantified as 5; 0.02–0.05 was quantified as 4; 0.05–0.2 was quantified as 3; 0.2–0.5 was quantified as 2; and 0.5–1 was quantified as 1, as shown in Table 7 Table 7 Quantification of dust release potential parameters in the ART model Table 7 Exposure parameter Parameter type options Model scoring Quantize Dust particle size Extremely light and fine powder 1.00 1 Fine dust 0.30 2 Coarse dust 0.10 3 Granules, flakes 0.03 4 Large pellets, flakes 0.01 5 ART, Advanced REACH Tool. ART, Advanced REACH Tool. Fig. 3 The dust exposure evaluated by the ART model was positively correlated with the exposure duration, with a correlation coefficient of 0.23 that is between 0.1 and 0.3, which is a weak correlation. The other parameters were negatively correlated; the correlation coefficient of surface contamination/emission with exposure was -0.72 that is between -0.7 and -0.9, which is a strong correlation. The other parameters were in the range of -0.3 and -0.7, which is a medium correlation, and the moisture content had the strongest correlation with exposure (correlation coefficient of -0.82). In addition, there was a correlation among the influencing factors, and the interactions of the influencing factors also affected the assessment of the final exposure results. Therefore, the ART model was further analyzed by regression analysis, with the exposure being the dependent variable and the influencing factors being the independent variables, to evaluate the specific relationships between the influencing factors and the exposure. 3.5 Regression analysis of influencing factors The ART model assessment results of welding fume exposure were set as the dependent variable Y, the exposure duration X1, dust particle size X2, moisture content X3, local control X4, segregation X5, dispersion X6, individual separation X7, and surface contamination/emissions X8. Specifically, an increase in moisture content significantly reduced the diffusion of the welding fumes, thus reducing their exposure impact. Strengthening the control of the degree of surface contamination/emissions can reduce the impact of welding fumes on exposures. The size of the dust particles had a significant effect on the suspension characteristics of welding fumes; i.e., smaller particles are easier to suspend in the air, increasing the risk of inhalation. 4 Discussion In summary, this paper compares the field data of welding fume exposure with the assessment results of the ART model. The results showed that there was a strong agreement between the assessment results at the 95th percentile and the field data. We adopted the multiple covariance diagnoses method to identify the influencing factors that could be quantitatively analyzed, and combined a Kendall correlation analysis and regression analysis to evaluate the relationship between the changes in welding fume exposure due to the influencing factors in the electric welding process. In this section, the effects of various parameters in the ART model on the measured exposure and detailed information about the different influencing factors are discussed to facilitate the targeted increase in control measures and protect workers from welding fume-related injuries. 1. Although awareness of the hazards of welding fumes has increased in recent years, many people involved in welding lack awareness, especially of the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC’s) reclassification of welding fumes as carcinogens [ 24 24 25 2. Comparison of the welding processes of the 18 building materials enterprises with the ART model assessment results and welding fume concentration data that were measured onsite showed that the 95th percentile assessment value and the measured value had a high degree of consistency, and the model used in the assessment of higher or lower values may have a certain degree of conservatism. As in a previous study, the ART model tends to overestimate lower exposures and underestimate higher exposures [ 26 3. The ART model for welding fume exposure assessment in building materials enterprises was influenced mainly by moisture content, dust particle size, and surface contamination/emissions. For example, the literature emphasizes the importance of controlling dust particle size and workplace humidity in occupational health [ 27 4. Localized control, although with near-zero coefficients, are a cause for concern because even small changes can have an impact on worker exposure over long periods of time or in high-intensity operations. In addition, the negative impacts of segregation, dispersion, and individual separation indicate the importance of these factors in reducing exposure. Money proposed that in order to strengthen occupational health control, factories should improve segregation facilities [ 28 29 30 The results provide specific guidance for the development and implementation of methods for controlling the spread of welding fumes in welding workplaces and a scientific basis for the development of targeted occupational health interventions. 5 Conclusion This study revealed that moisture content, dust particle size, and surface contamination/emissions are the main factors that influence welding fume exposure and that control strategies that target influencing factors can be developed and implemented to reduce the exposure risk to workers. It is recommended that building materials enterprises should be able to adjust and optimize welding fume control measures in a timely manner. For workplaces with high concentrations of welding fumes, enterprises should promptly implement effective control measures to mitigate occupational health risks. This study has several limitations. First, only 18 building materials enterprises were analyzed and the sample size should be increased in future research to validate the study’s findings. In future studies, the ART model may be applied in comparative analyses to evaluate exposures across different enterprise types or to various substances, thereby enhancing its applicability.
